Description: Terracotta mould-made female figure wearing pierced pointed hat and veil. Head fragment. Pierced with hole through the top of head, done when leather hard before firing. White coating with black paint preserved on some areas of hair. Light pink-brown fabric with biff surfaces. Abundant fine silver mica, quartz, grog and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Late classical or early Ptolemaic example. Not made from a Nile Delta fabric, either imported or more likely from Alexandria. A similar head from Sicily was dated to the end of the 5th century BC (Higgins 1964, no.165). '66' written on back in pencil.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.028) (Phase 1)
